questions.text: A 42-year-old woman came with complaints of swallowing difficulties, dysarthria, fluctuating limb muscle weakness, and bilateral eyelid ptosis with incomplete occlusion. A 45-year-old female presents with complaints of frequency, urgency and a sense of incomplete evacuation for 1 year. She is non-diabetic. Her past ultrasounds, urine examination, and high vaginal swab cultures have no pathology. On pelvic examination, there is no significant vaginal discharge. Cystoscopy is normal. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Name Urethral Syndrome
Definition A collection of symptoms related to the urethra, characterized by pain, discomfort, and urinary symptoms. It is not a widely recognized medical condition.
Common Symptoms - Urethral pain or discomfort - Frequent urge to urinate - Burning sensation during urination - Increased urinary frequency - Dysuria (painful urination) - In some cases, urinary urgency and incontinence
Possible Causes Urethral syndrome is not well-defined and can have various potential causes, including infection, inflammation, irritation, and neurological factors.
Diagnosis Diagnosis is often based on the exclusion of other urinary conditions, such as urinary tract infections (UTIs) and sexually transmitted infections (STIs). Tests may include urine culture, urethral swab, and cystoscopy.
Treatment Treatment may vary depending on the underlying cause. It could include: - Antibiotics for infections - Medications to manage symptoms (e.g., antispasmodics) - Lifestyle changes (e.g., dietary modifications, pelvic floor exercises) - Physical therapy - Stress management and relaxation techniques
Prognosis The prognosis for urethral syndrome depends on the underlying cause and how well it responds to treatment.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient was brought in with complaints of postural instability. Post examination, you confirm that it has nothing to do with vertigo and suspect it could be of cerebellar origin. Which of the following symptoms cannot be seen in cerebellar lesions?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Resting tremors:

Feature Resting Tremors Intentional Tremors
Definition Tremors that occur when muscles are at rest and completely supported against gravity. Tremors that occur during voluntary movement or intentional actions.
Characteristics Typically present in conditions like Parkinson's disease. Characterized by a rhythmic, oscillatory movement. Tremors are often associated with conditions such as essential tremors or cerebellar disorders. They are usually more noticeable during specific tasks or movements.
Trigger Often exacerbated by stress or emotional factors. Typically triggered or worsened by movement or purposeful actions.
Frequency Generally occurs at a frequency of 4-6 Hz. The frequency may vary depending on the task or movement being performed.
Location Commonly affects hands, fingers, forearms, jaw, and lips. It can affect various body parts depending on the task, but it often affects hands and arms.
Progression Tends to worsen over time as the underlying condition progresses. May remain stable or worsen with age, depending on the underlying cause.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents to the ophthalmology OPD with complaints of redness, photophobia, and decreased visual acuity for the last 2.5 months. He gave his history of contact with cats . On his ocular examination, severe vitritis was associated with a focal necrotizing chorioretinitis on the posterior segment. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - 

Condition

Causative Agent

Ocular Features

Signs and Findings

Treatment

Toxoplasmosis

Toxoplasma gondii

Granulomatous or non-granulomatous uveitis
  • Posterior segment involvement with punched-out lesions and pigmented margin
  • Severe vitritis leading to "headlight in fog" appearance during active inflammation
  • Macular involvement during healing

Triple therapy: Pyrimethamine + Sulfadiazine + Clindamycin. Steroids under the cover of these drugs. Intravitreal Clindamycin with dexamethasone may be used.

Onchocerciasis

Onchocerca volvulus

Non-granulomatous uveitis
  • Anterior or posterior uveitis
  • Sclerosing keratitis leading to corneal opacity
  • River blindness

Ivermectin (primary treatment). Prophylactic steroids to control inflammation. IV Suramin for adult worms.

Cysticercosis

Taenia solium larvae

Intense vitritis. Cysts or larvae in subretinal space
  • Conjunctival cysts
  • Free-floating cysts in the anterior chamber
  • Cysts or larvae in the subretinal space
  • Involvement of extraocular muscles (e.g., superior rectus) leading to pain, swelling, and restricted eye movements

Systemic steroids for inflammation. Albendazole under steroid cover. Surgical removal of cysts if necessary.

Toxocariasis

Toxocara canis

Anterior uveitis, posterior uveitis, chronic endophthalmitis, vitritis
  • Anterior or posterior uveitis
  • Chorioretinitis
  • Chronic endophthalmitis leading to leukocoria and strabismus
  • Vitritis

Systemic anti-parasitic medications, corticosteroids, surgery if needed.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presents to the emergency room after he s ustained a road traffic accident . His blood pressure is 88/76 mm Hg, and his pulse rate is 126 per minute . On examination, he appears pale and somnolent. Which of the following correctly represents the formula of the Modified Shock Index (MSI) ?
questions.correct_answer: C. Heart rate / Mean arterial pressure
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C: Heart rate / Mean arterial pressu

Shock index

Modified shock index
  • Heart rate divided by systolic BP
  • Better marker for assessing the severity of shock than heart rate & BP alone
  • Utility in trauma patients, sepsis, obstetrics, myocardial infarction, stroke & other acute critical illnesses.
  • Correlated with the need for interventions such as blood transfusion & invasive procedure, including surgery
  • SI is known as a hemodynamic stability indicator
  • SI does not take into account the diastolic BP
  • Heart rate divided by mean arterial pressure
  • High MSI indicates a value of stroke volume & low systemic vascular resistance, a sign of hypodynamic circulation
  • Low MSI indicates a hyperdynamic state
  • MSI has been considered a better marker than SI for mortality rate prediction

questions.correct_answer: C. Obstruction of hair follicles by head lice eggs (nits)
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C- Obstruction of hair follicles by head lice eggs (nits)

Pediculosis

Definition

Infestation of the scalp, body, or pubic hair by lice (Pediculus humanus capitis, corporis, or pubis).

Types

- Pediculus humanus capitis (Head Lice): Affects the scalp and hair.

- Pediculus humanus corporis (Body Lice): Infests clothing and feeds on blood.

- Pthirus pubis (Pubic Lice): Infests coarse body hair, especially in the genital area.

Transmission

Direct contact with an infested person, or indirect contact with infested personal items such as combs, hats, or clothing.

Symptoms

- Intense itching in the affected area.

- Presence of lice or nits (eggs) on hair or clothing.

- Secondary bacterial infections due to scratching.

Common Sites

- Head lice: Scalp and hair.

- Body lice: Clothing and areas of the body covered by clothing.

- Pubic lice: Genital and coarse body hair.

Diagnosis

Identification of live lice, nymphs, or nits on hair or clothing through visual inspection.

Treatment

- Topical Pediculicides: Over-the-counter or prescription shampoos or lotions containing insecticides (e.g., permethrin, pyrethrins, malathion).

- Manual Removal: Combing hair with a fine-toothed comb to remove lice and nits.

- Environmental Cleaning: Washing infested clothing, bedding, and personal items.

Preventive Measures

- Avoiding head-to-head contact with infested individuals.

- Not sharing personal items like combs, brushes, or hats.

- Laundering and hot drying of infested clothing and bedding.

Complications

- Secondary bacterial infections from scratching.

- Psychological distress due to social stigma.

questions.text: What term best describes the phenomenon exhibited by a 35- year-old male who while speaking, switches topics abruptly and displays continuous speech flow with no pauses or breaks?

Term Definition
Derailment Also known as loosening of associations, where ideas slip off track onto unrelated tangents. Unlike flight of ideas, connections are not logical or understandable.
Thought blocking A sudden interruption in speech or thought, where the patient abruptly stops speaking, often reporting a “blank mind.” Seen in schizophrenia.
Neologism The creation of new, meaningless words that are not part of any recognized language. Common in schizophrenia.

Attico-Antral

Treatment of primary pathology

It can be treated with ear surgery depending on the extent of the disease.

It can be treated with reconstructive surgery like myringoplasty or tympanoplasty.

6th Nerve Palsy

questions.text: To which Runyon's classification group do Mycobacterium gordonae, a slow-growing mycobacterium producing a yellow-orange pigment regardless of light conditions, belong?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - Group II

Runyon's Classification

Description

Group 1 (Photochromogens)

This group includes mycobacteria that produce pigments when exposed to light, such as Mycobacterium kansasii and Mycobacterium marinum. They appear yellow-orange or buff-colored on culture.

Group 2 (Scotochromogens)

Mycobacteria in this group produce pigments in the dark but not in the light. Examples include Mycobacterium scrofulaceum and Mycobacterium szulgai. They show a variable range of colors.

Group 3 (Non-chromogens)

This group includes mycobacteria that do not produce any pigments. Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) and Mycobacterium intracellulare are common examples found in this group.

Group 4 (Rapid growers)

Mycobacteria in this group are fast-growing and can produce visible colonies on culture within 7 days. Examples include Mycobacterium fortuitum and Mycobacterium chelonae.

questions.text: All are methods of Controlled tipping except
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Bangalore meth

The trench method:
  • Most commonly used
  • In this method, the ground is dug and the solid waste is buried in it. The solid waste is then covered with the mud
  • Trench is dug where level ground is available
  • A 2-3-meter-deep with 4-12 meters width trench is dug
  • For a population of 10,000, a two-meter-deep trench is dug up, and one-acre land is required

Ramp method

  • Suited for moderately sloping terrain

Area method

  • Land depressions, disused quarries and clay pits are filled with refuse
  • Disadvantage: It requires supplemental earth from outside source

Technique in controlled tipping (Trench method)
  • Burying of solid waste leads to physical, bacteriological and chemical changes in the buried refuse
  • The temperature rises to 60°C after 7 days of burial of refuse killing all pathogens followed by the decomposition process
  • Complete decomposition of organic matter into an innocuous mass (made up of soil) occurs within 4-6 months. This end product is used as manure in farming
  • This further cools down in 2-3 weeks

questions.text: A 30-year-old adult presents with a sore throat and fever. On examination, the tonsils are red and enlarged, but there are no whitish yellow dots or a membrane present. Which type of tonsillitis is most likely present in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C: Acute parench

Types of Tonsillitis

Description

Clinical Features

Acute Tonsillitis
  • Disease present for <4 weeks
  • Most common in school-going children
    - Rare in infants and adults >50 years old
 
  • Etiology: Group A β Hemolytic streptococcus is the most common infecting organism
  • May cause myocarditis, glomerulonephritis, polyarthritis, and rheumatic fever due to cross-reactivity
     

Acute Superficial Tonsillitis
  • Infection limited to superficial mucosa of the tonsil
  • Only redness observed, no enlargement of the tonsils

Acute Follicular Tonsillitis
  • Infection reaches the crypts of the tonsils, pus is present in crypts
  • Whitish yellow dots seen on the surface of the tonsils

Acute Parenchymal Tonsillitis
  • Infection reaches the parenchyma of the tonsils
  • Tonsils become red and enlarged

Acute Membranous Tonsillitis
  • Pearly white membrane forms on the tonsils due to dead tissues and debris
  • Membrane is a true membrane, only present on the tonsils and doesn't spread to surrounding structures
 
  • Peeling the membrane does not cause bleeding in the underlying structure

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with symptoms of memory loss, identity confusion, and sudden unexplained travels. Upon evaluation, you observe that the patient seems unconcerned and indifferent towards these symptoms. The patient denies any distress or impairment. Treatment

Description

Psychotherapy
  • Behavior Therapy: Focuses on current symptoms and minimizing secondary and tertiary gains.
  • Abreaction: Brings unconscious memories and emotions to awareness using techniques like hypnosis and free association.
  • Psychodynamic Psychotherapy: Explores underlying psychological conflicts and develops healthier coping mechanisms.

Pharmacotherapy
  • Limited role in treating dissociative disorders.
  • Benzodiazepines: Short-term use for anxiety relief.
  • Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors (SSRIs): Used for comorbid depression.

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida with twin pregnancies has discordant twins on transvaginal ultrasound at 37 weeks of gestation. She is advised to have an elective LSCS. What should be the weight difference between two babies in discordant twins?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: 15% with the smaller twin as an index

options.label: C
options.text: 20% with the larger twin as an index

options.label: D
options.text: 25% with the smaller twin as an index

questions.correct_answer: C. 20% with the larger twin as an index
questions.explanation:
Definition Discordant twins are a pair of twins (usually monozygotic or dizygotic) who exhibit significant differences in various aspects, such as birth weight, size, or developmental milestones.
Types Discordance can manifest in different ways, including weight discordance, size discordance (length or head circumference), or developmental discordance (e.g., one twin reaching developmental milestones before the other).
Causes Discordance can result from a variety of factors, including differences in placental sharing, genetic factors, nutritional supply within the womb, and other environmental influences.
Health Implications Discordant twins may face increased health risks, with the smaller or less developed twin being more vulnerable. These risks may include preterm birth, low birth weight, and various complications.
Monitoring and Intervention Healthcare providers closely monitor discordant twins during pregnancy to detect and address potential issues. Interventions may include specialized prenatal care, nutritional support, and early delivery in some cases.
Growth Discordance Weight discordance, where one twin significantly outweighs the other, is a common type of discordance. Severe cases may be referred to as selective intrauterine growth restriction (sIUGR).

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents to the dermatology clinic with complaints of thickened, discolored nails. He mentions that he has been experiencing this problem for several months and has noticed a gradual deterioration in the appearance of his nails. On examination, the patient's nails exhibit yellowish discoloration, subungual hyperkeratosis, and onycholysis. There are no signs of inflammation or pain. Based on the clinical scenario, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D- Tinea Unguiu

Tinea Unguium (Onychomycosis)

Definition

Fungal infection of the nails, commonly caused by dermatophyte fungi.

Causative Agents

Dermatophytes (e.g., Trichophyton spp., Epidermophyton floccosum, Microsporum spp.) and occasionally yeasts.

Clinical Presentation

- Yellowish Discoloration: Commonly presents as yellow or white discoloration of the affected nails.
 

- Subungual Hyperkeratosis: Thickening of the nail plate under the nail.
 

- Onycholysis: Separation of the nail from the nail bed, often starting at the tips or sides.
 

- Brittle Nails: Nails may become brittle and prone to breakage.

Risk Factors

- Aging, as nail structure changes over time.
 

- Trauma to the nails.
 

- Warm and humid environments favor fungal growth.
 

- Immunocompromised individuals are more susceptible.

Diagnostic Methods

- Fungal Culture: Identifies the specific fungi causing the infection.
 

- Microscopic Examination: Visualization of fungal elements in nail samples (KOH preparation).
 

- Nail Biopsy: Rarely performed but may be done in certain cases.

Treatment

- Topical Antifungals: Applied directly to the affected nails (e.g., ciclopirox).
 

- Oral Antifungals: Systemic medications (e.g., terbinafine, itraconazole) for severe or widespread cases.
 

- Nail Debridement: Trimming and removal of infected nail material.

Prevention

- Keep nails clean and dry.
 

- Avoid sharing personal items like nail clippers.
 

- Wear breathable footwear and change socks regularly.

Prognosis

- Treatment may require several months for complete resolution.
 

- Recurrence is possible, and preventive measures are important.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the major Modified Duke Criteria in infective endocarditis?

options.label: A
options.text: Transthoracic echocardiography is better than Transesophageal echocardiography

options.label: B
options.text: Coxiella requires only single positive culture for diagnosis

options.label: C
options.text: New onset murmur in previously healthy person with no heart lesions

options.label: D
options.text: Janeways lesion and roth spots are included in major criteria

questions.correct_answer: B. Coxiella requires only single positive culture for diagnosis
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - Coxiella requires only a single positive vulture for diag

Major Criteria

Description and Characteristics

1. Positive Blood Culture
  • Typical organisms are positive from 2 separate blood cultures.
  • Typical organisms include Streptococcus viridans from the oral cavity or skin, Streptococcus gallolyticus from the GI tract, Staphylococcus aureus, and HACEK group bacteria.
  • Persistently positive blood culture: Typical organisms isolated from blood cultures done more than 12 hours apart.
  • Single positive blood culture: Coxiella infection (Coxiella burnetii), which causes Q fever. It is zoonotic and associated with Phase I IgG titre > 1:800.

2. Echocardiographic Evidence
  • Types of echocardiography used for evaluation include Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) and Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE).
  • TEE is considered more sensitive than TTE for detecting endocardial involvement and vegetations.
  • Vegetation or oscillating intracardiac mass on imaging.
  • Vegetation < 2 mm in size may be missed on Transthoracic echocardiography.
  • Partial dehiscence of a prosthetic valve or new valvular regurgitation due to damage by bacterial infection.

3. New Onset Murmur in Patient with Pre-existing Heart Lesion
  • Development of a new heart murmur in a patient with a pre-existing heart lesion.

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient presents to the ENT clinic with a complaint of hearing loss and recurrent ear infections. Upon examination, you notice a perforation in the tympanic membrane. As you assess the characteristics of the perforation, you recall the different types of tympanic membrane perforations. Based on the provided information, answer the following question: What type of perforation involves all the quadrants of the pars tensa, but the annulus is intact?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D - Subtotal

Type of Perforation

Description

Central Perforation

A perforation that occurs in the central area of the pars tensa of the tympanic membrane, without involving the annulus.

Attic Perforation

A perforation specifically involving the pars flaccida of the tympanic membrane, typically located in the upper part of the membrane near the superior part of the malleus handle.

Small Central Perforation

A perforation limited to a single quadrant of the pars tensa, usually in the central portion of the membrane.

Large Central Perforation

A perforation involving more than one quadrant of the pars tensa, extending beyond a single area of the membrane.

Subtotal Perforation

A perforation involving all the quadrants of the pars tensa but with the annulus remaining intact, meaning the fibrous cartilaginous ring surrounding the membrane is not disrupted.

Total Perforation

A perforation involving all the quadrants of the pars tensa and also extending through the annulus, resulting in a complete rupture of the tympanic membrane.
